Chronological order. Mises should be between Eugen and Fred but he was (technically) from an area which is now part of the Ukraine. Mises is the key plank between early and late Austrians.

I hate to be "anal" but it's "analyzing" not "analysing". Z. Not S. Clear typo. And this para should be deleted anyway.

Added "comparatively" - meaning compared to the early years. Menger and Bohm-Bawerk thought "truth" would win out, and "allowed" the School to collapse. They should have fought much harder.

it's status is not obscure, it itself is somewhat obscure; "it does have a long" is redundant to "it has a long"; Hayek was far too late to be an initial supporter and von Mises' line is over-detailed
let's take this step by step; humans have beliefs, economic schools don't; "at least...and little else" is redundant; "taxing" modifier is redundant; and views must be attributed

Wholesale deleting/editing unacceptable. EL's that are not mainstream but DIRECTLY applicable to this topic should NOT be deleted.

copyedit lede, remove undue wieght towards Paul/Hayek, questionable claims etc., trim see also and external links
Please don't try to fix a School of Thought you openly oppose and believe is "witchcraft". Inherently POV edits given your stated position. Please work on mainstream.
Header was rewritten to make unsupported claims. Noting that.
Sorry. I'm trying to avoid the "harshness" of the words "strict enforcement" (as though it's a Nazi police state idea). It simply means maximum opennes to voluntary contracting.

readers unfamilar with Krugman can follow the link
Probably tried to fit too much in here. Just note: Public goods are a completely different issue and government has a role to play here. Don't know where to put analysis of public goods...
/* Inflation */ It sounds very strange hearing a title before a very well known person, unless that person is a knight (Even then, it's sporadic: [Sir] Elton John vs. Anthony Hopkins)
Can we at least keep the wording neutral and genuinely NPOV? By the way, neo-Keynesian economics needs a knowledgeable contributor to flesh out the content...
An academic institution is accredited, has enrolled students, regular classes and grants degrees.
Mises Institute is "non-academic"? You have got to be kidding. It's a place of higher learning, that's for sure.
Please see talk page. I've given it a go. I hope it's more accessible to the non-praxeologists who don't now about methodologial individualism or the heterogeneity of capital
